media.caption: the flag of Australia is used

media.alt: The northeastern slopes of Big Ben volcano on Heard Island are visible in shadow at the top right of this photo. Mawson Peak (small circle in the upper center of the image), sits within a breached caldera (collapsed and empty magma chamber beneath a volcano) on the southwestern side of the volcano - the shadow cast by Mawson Peak points directly to the crescent-shaped caldera rim. This image, taken during the Southern Hemisphere summer, also shows the dark brown volcanic rock that forms the island. The southwest-pointing tongue of ice is Gotley Glacier. Image credit: NASA.
media.caption: The northeastern slopes of Big Ben volcano on Heard Island are visible in shadow at the top right of this photo. Mawson Peak (small circle in the upper center of the image), sits within a breached caldera (collapsed and empty magma chamber beneath a volcano) on the southwestern side of the volcano - the shadow cast by Mawson Peak points directly to the crescent-shaped caldera rim. This image, taken during the Southern Hemisphere summer, also shows the dark brown volcanic rock that forms the island. The southwest-pointing tongue of ice is Gotley Glacier. Image credit: NASA.

media.alt: In October 2012, satellites measured subtle signals that suggested volcanic activity on remote Heard Island. These images, captured several months later, show proof of an eruption on Mawson Peak. By early April 2013, Mawson's steep-walled summit crater had filled, and a trickle of lava had spilled down the volcano's southwestern flank. Image courtesy of NASA.
media.caption: In October 2012, satellites measured subtle signals that suggested volcanic activity on remote Heard Island. These images, captured several months later, show proof of an eruption on Mawson Peak. By early April 2013, Mawson's steep-walled summit crater had filled, and a trickle of lava had spilled down the volcano's southwestern flank. Image courtesy of NASA.

media.alt: This image shows vortex shedding occurring as winds pass Heard Island (in the lower left) resulting in a K치rm치n vortex street - a repeating pattern of swirling vortices - in the clouds. Photo courtesy of NASA.

fields.name: Background
fields.content: The UK transferred these uninhabited, barren, sub-Antarctic islands to Australia in 1947. Populated by large numbers of seal and bird species, the islands have been designated a nature preserve.

fields.name: Location
fields.content: islands in the Indian Ocean, about two-thirds of the way from Madagascar to Antarctica

fields.name: Map references
fields.content: Antarctic Region

fields.content:
total: 412 sq km

land: 412 sq km

water: 0 sq km

fields.content: slightly more than two times the size of Washington, DC

fields.content:
territorial sea: 12 nm

exclusive fishing zone: 200 nm

fields.name: Climate
fields.content: antarctic

fields.name: Terrain
fields.content: Heard Island - 80% ice-covered, bleak and mountainous, dominated by a large massif (Big Ben) and an active volcano (Mawson Peak); McDonald Islands - small and rocky

highest point: Mawson Peak on Big Ben volcano 2,745 m

agricultural land: 0% (2011 est.)

other: 100% (2018 est.)

fields.name: Natural hazards
fields.content: Mawson Peak, an active volcano, is on Heard Island

fields.name: Environment - current issues
fields.content: none; uninhabited and mostly ice covered

fields.name: Geography - note
fields.content: Mawson Peak on Heard Island is the highest Australian mountain (at 2,745 meters, it is taller than Mt. Kosciuszko in Australia proper), and one of only two active volcanoes located in Australian territory, the other being McDonald Island; in 1992, McDonald Island broke its dormancy and began erupting; it has erupted several times since, most recently in 2005

fields.name: Population
fields.content: uninhabited

fields.name: Country name
fields.content:
conventional long form: Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands

conventional short form: Heard Island and McDonald Islands

abbreviation: HIMI

etymology: named after American Captain John HEARD, who sighted the island on 25 November 1853, and American Captain William McDONALD, who discovered the islands on 4 January 1854

fields.name: Dependency status
fields.content: territory of Australia; administered from Canberra by the Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities (Australian Antarctic Division)

fields.name: Legal system
fields.content: the laws of Australia apply where applicable

fields.name: Diplomatic representation in the US
fields.content: none (territory of Australia)

fields.name: Diplomatic representation from the US
fields.content: embassy: none (territory of Australia)

fields.name: Flag description
fields.content: the flag of Australia is used

fields.name: Economic overview
fields.content: The islands have no indigenous economic activity, but the Australian Government allows limited fishing in the surrounding waters. Visits to Heard Island typically focus on terrestrial and marine research and infrequent private expeditions.

fields.content: .hm

fields.name: Ports and terminals
fields.content: none; offshore anchorage only

fields.name: Military - note
fields.content: defense is the responsibility of Australia; Australia conducts fisheries patrols

fields.name: Disputes - international
fields.content: none
